captions.text: I am here to tell you about my first time.
This here is the Trimaker I, a 3D printer.
3D printers are machines[br]that allow us to make things,
to build our own objects.
I think 3D printers will change[br]the world in the next few years,
they will change our lives.
As a child I always liked[br]working with my hands.
I liked to build my own toys.
I remember how[br]the feeling of building my own toy
was totally different[br]from having one that was bought.
I used dad's tools for this,
which were my inspiration.
At the age of 6, I remember[br]electrocuting myself for the first time.
I was fixing a small Christmas tree.
It happened again when I was 14,[br]and it was more powerful.
I remember I was fixing granddad's drill.
I didn't notice I was barefoot.
I plugged it in, and immediately[br]my body started shaking.
I felt how the electricity[br]went through my hands,
my body, then my feet,
and I was thrown to the ground.
Somebody helped me.
After such a practical lesson,[br]my Italian granddad came and said:
"Ma, bambino, siediti qui."
"I am going to give you[br]the theoretical lesson."
I can promise you I never forgot
what the power wire[br]and a ground discharge were.
Time passed
and I kept building my own toys,
but each time a bit more complex.
A friend of mine, Dan Etenberg,[br]built this turbine.
We loved getting together[br]to do this kind of crazy stuff.
He calls and says: "Hey, Maxi,[br]listen: I finished the turbine,
I finished solving that thing[br]we had to mill...
I'm going to your granddad's!
Can you imagine granddad's face
when we told him we were putting[br]a turbine in the garden?
Granddad shut himself in the kitchen.
We were bringing a device this big,[br]that could turn at 130,000 rpm.,
that needed protection[br]in case the blades went flying out
and it also threw a 16-inch flame.[br]And the noise it made...
I can't push it out of my mind...
It was as if a Sky Harrier[br]was landing in granddad's garden.
I think he might have thought that,[br]that a helicopter was landing.
I asked Dan afterwards:[br]"Hey, Dan, what can we build now?
How about building a laser?"
We were good boys,[br]but we enjoyed these things.
Of course, a laser beam.[br]We had to be very careful.
If we touched that aluminum part[br]in the discharge tube...
There were 30,000 volts going through it!
But we liked these things[br]and we wanted to do what we enjoyed.
That lab was like Frankenstein's.
After some time I said,[br]among other things:
"Well, I don't want to keep asking[br]for dad's tools,
and this time I will build[br]my own stuff, with a milling machine."
A milling machine is a Cartesian robot[br]that withdraws material
from a plastic or wooden block[br]until it builds what you can see there
which can be any kind of object.
It was around 10 months of building[br]to obtain the object in 1 hour.
We were just watching the machine work.
There was an incredible intensity.
But there was a question[br]I could not answer myself:
Can one live off what's fun to do?
Or are entertainment and work[br]like water and oil?
Do they mix?
Can you mix fun with business opportunity?
This is how I started getting into[br]the subject of 3D printers.
Because it was a technology[br]that kept me awake at night
and that, additionally, I saw[br]as a possible business opportunity.
But, I recall I started out saying
I was here to tell you[br]about my first time, right?
The first time I printed[br]with a 3D printer I made by myself.
Let me introduce you: This is Marsi 1.
Yes, it looks like[br]an ice-cream machine.
But believe me, it was a 3D printer.
My first time was disastrous.
I tried for 3 months[br]and nothing happened, nothing at all.
I remember I had already[br]spoken with investors,
I was giving talks[br]at the University of Buenos Aires,
telling everyone that I was building[br]a 3D printer that did not print
and that the only thing it did was this.
I wanted to do a bracelet,[br]all I got was that smashed thing.
I wanted to do Star-Wars' Yoda,
I got that fried egg you can see there.
Every time that happened to me,[br]it felt like being stabbed in the chest.
I went to bed very sad.
Until one day, I decided[br]not to pay any attention to it any more.
This story is 100% true.
I would always stand there,[br]watching for two hours,
and this would come out.
This time I went[br]to the supermarket and left her.
As if on purpose,[br]when I came back I found this.
You don't know how I felt!
I was literally jumping for joy.
Imagine arriving and seeing[br]"Venus de Milo" hanging there.
It was 2 x 2 x 3 cm,
but to me, it was like touching heaven[br]with my hands.
It improved, little by little.
And we started printing other things.
I am going to talk a bit[br]about the technology.
Can you see that white pan?
A photosensitive resin is placed there.
And it is illuminated from beneath,[br]layer by layer,
the level surfaces are projected
until the morphology[br]one has programmed and designed is built.
There you can see my favorite figure,[br]which is "The Clay Bottle."
And over there, that green figure, is me.
Don't tell, but I want to give it[br]to my girlfriend as a birthday present.
Good idea?
What we are building with now
are different types of rubber[br]and wax components,
we are printing in plastic,[br]different colours.
Here you can see[br]the "Venus de Milo" keyring.
That was the first.[br]It brings good luck, I hope.
So you can see that not only[br]about the useless things I just showed you
but this technology, nowadays,[br]is changing people's lives.
That small girl had[br]parts of her body scanned.
An exoskeleton was printed
and it was able to alleviate[br]the mobility problem she had.
Below that, you can see a jaw.
That mandible was built[br]using selective laser melting technology
with aluminum powder.
It was created for an 83 year-old woman,[br]who can now move her jaw.
This is Marina.
She is my cousin.
In 2006, she had a very serious accident,
a car accident.
The doctors weren't very optimistic.
The truth is it shocked[br]the whole family very badly.
She had multiple injuries of all kinds.
One of the worst was a head injury.
She had lost part[br]of the bone structure in her head.
There were 2 options.
One was to stick[br]to traditional treatments.
It meant taking a kind of[br]bio-compatible coating texture
and putting it in place[br]in an almost manual fashion,
until the part of the skull[br]that was missing was covered.
The second option
was taking a CT scan
and digitally building the cranium[br]directly from that scan.
And afterwards, the part that was missing
would be rebuilt in software[br]to be finally printed in 3D.
They went with the second option.
Today, Marina enjoys a splendid life,
she has 2 children,[br]enjoys time with her family
and has just run a marathon.
I hope that what started out[br]as simply having fun,
can help people in the future.
This makes me think[br]it is possible to do what makes you happy,
and that it's possible[br]to change the world,
while feeling like it's the first time.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Mi primera vez... con una impresora 3D: Maximiliano Bertotto at TEDxUTN
